result.execSummary:
The defendant Harley D McKay was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Burglary-Building or Dwelling [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).
  • Burglary-Building or Dwelling [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(1m)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
Defendant IS eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program.
Defendant IS NOT eligible for Substance Abuse Program.
Apply 181 days sentence credit.

superMiscConds.notes:
Restitution to be paid joint/several as follows:  $519.35 payable to Douglas C., $1,448.69 payable to William & Janalee P., $1,170.22 payable to David G., $500 payable to John S., $504.18 payable to Dean M., $50 payable to Hannah H., $199.98 payable to Jessica M., $31 payable to Oralis A., $10 payable to Abigail C., $9.00 payable to Jakob D.
Restitution is to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision and to be paid BEFORE costs/fines.

  If Probation/Extended Supervision is revoked and/or a prison term ordered, outstanding financial obligations shall be collected pursuant to statutory provisions, including deductions from inmate prison monies.  If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  Collections may include income assignment.
Court costs ($278) and DNA surcharge ($250) are to be paid as a Condition of Extended Supervision.
Maintain employment and/or combination of schooling.
AODA assessment and follow through with any treatment recommended.
Mental health evaluation and treatment deemed appropriate.

ABSOLUTE SOBRIETY.
Submit to random urine screens.
No use or possession of alcohol, illegal drugs or drug paraphernalia.
No use or possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription.
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of any and all prescriptions.
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent.
No association with known drug users or dealers and no contact at any place where illegal drugs are purchased, used, stored, packaged and distributed.
No presence on any premises whose primary business is serving or selling alcohol (for example, bars, taverns or liquor stores).
Criminal Thinking Class.
Provide DNA sample if not yet provided.
No contact with any of the victims listed in the criminal complaint or their residences.
No contact with any of the co-actors.

Timothy Suha appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Harley D McKay in court, in custody (OTP'd From Racine Youthfull Offender Facility), with attorney Joseph James Dorlack.

State presented their sentencing recommendations.
Defense presented their sentencing recommendations.



Court orders the following:
Count 1:
Total Prison: 10  Years.
Initial Confinement:  5  Years.
Extended Supervision: 5  Years.
561 Days Credit.

CONDITIONS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION:  
AODA Assessment and follow through with any treatment if agent deems appropriate.
Absolute Sobriety;  Random U.A.'s ; 
No Use or Possession of alcohol, controlled substances or drug paraphernalia.
No Use or Possession of prescription drugs without a valid prescription;
Any valid prescription drugs must be taken only in the manner in which they are prescribed.
Inform Agent of all prescriptions
Follow through with any treatment and/or counseling recommended by Agent;
Defendant to obtain his high school diploma or GED.
Maintain employment and/or combination of schooling upon release from custody.
No contact with:  any of the victims listed in the criminal complaint or their residence on any of the cases including read in lists and dismissed and read in cases, or any co-actors.
DNA sample to be provided.
No association with known drug users or dealers and no contact at any place where illegal drugs are purchased, used, stored, packaged, or distributed.

Previously ordered Restitution:  $4,442.42 Joint/Several with Co-Actors (see attached Restitution Summary Sheets for Breakdown and Cases -  restitution to be paid before costs or fines);
Additional Restitution Ordered on Case 15CF273:  $3,408.00 Joint/Several with Co-Actors (see attached Restitution Summary Sheets for Breakdown and Cases -  restitution to be paid before costs or fines);

Costs:  $268
DNA Sample and Surcharge:  $250
DRGOD Surcharge:  $10
To be paid as a Condition of the Sentence (can be taken out of prison wages/trust accounts).

Defendant is eligible for Challenge Incarceration Program.
Defendant is not eligible for Substance Abuse Program.

Felony warnings, voting rights and firearms warnings given.

Ted S. Szczupakiewicz appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Defendant Harley D McKay in court (By Video Conference from Racine Youthful Offender Center), in custody, with attorney Jeffrey William Jensen.
Oral Ruling On:
Defense Postconviction Motion - Requesting court vacate the JOC and grant re-sentencing

Court finds/orders the following:  Reasons placed on the record.
There is a sufficient showing that a re-sentencing of the defendant is appropriate.
Court Grants - Defense request for Re-Sentencing.
However, court will not vacate the JOC at this time (that will allow the defendant to remain at RYOC pending re-sentencing).
Next court date will be for Re-Sentencing and a Corrected/Amended JOC will be prepared.
Court Orders an OTP for the next court date.
